articleContent.title: Chord: 13th in E (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 13th in E (Shape: G)

## Description:
The 13th chord in E using the G shape refers to a complex and rich-sounding chord that adds color and depth to music. This chord is constructed by combining the root note E, major third G#, perfect fifth B, dominant seventh D, major ninth F#, and thirteenth note C#. It is a jazzy and sophisticated chord that can add lush harmonies to a musical piece.

## Notes and Intervals:
- E (Root)
- G# (Major Third)
- B (Perfect Fifth)
- D (Dominant Seventh)
- F# (Major Ninth)
- C# (Thirteenth)

## Genre and Flavor:
The 13th chord in E (Shape: G) is often used in jazz, R&B, funk, and soul music genres. It brings a sophisticated and colorful harmonic flavor to compositions, providing a sense of richness and complexity to the music. This chord can create a sense of tension and release, adding depth and interest to harmonic progressions.

## Songs:
Here are three songs that feature the 13th chord in E (Shape: G):
1. "Fly Me to the Moon" by Frank Sinatra
2. "Isn't She Lovely" by Stevie Wonder
3. "So What" by Miles Davis

This chord can be heard in various sections of these songs, adding a jazzy and sophisticated vibe to the musical arrangements.
